questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine yearly visit. The patient has been well since her last visit without new concerns. She has a history of hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide and newly diagnosed Parkinson disease. The patient has not yet been seen by a neurologist and has an appointment scheduled for next week. The patient has no other significant medical or surgical history. The patient’s mother died of metastatic lung cancer, and the patient’s father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient drinks 1-2 alcoholic beverages each week, and she smoked one pack per day for 5 years when she was in her 40’s. She lives with her partner and has had several falls over the past six months. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 134/60 mmHg, heart rate is 80 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. BMI is 26.7 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. The patient is well-appearing, and a full physical examination is unremarkable except for a pin rolling tremor and masked facies. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Addition of a second antihypertensive medication
Low dose computed tomography (CT) chest imaging

questions.solution:
This patient presents for a well-patient geriatric care visit. She has newly diagnosed Parkinson disease and is at increased risk for falls. The next best step in management is to address any concerns and provide supportive measures, such as referral to physical therapy services. Physical therapists can make assessments and provide appropriate exercise regimens for patients to reduce the risk of falls. Additional measures that may decrease the risk of falls include removing loose rugs, using non-slip mats, and ensuring proper lighting in the home.

Providers should regularly ask older patients about recent falls and fall risks because of the high incidence and potential for fracture and hospitalization. All patients who have fallen or who have limited mobility that increases their risk for falls should be asked about contributing factors, such as polypharmacy and unsafe home environments. Effective interventions include physical therapy, assistive devices, and a supervised exercise program.

Option Analysis

✅ Referral to physical therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transfer to rehabilitation facility:
Incorrect: This patient is not in need of inpatient rehabilitation at this time. Physical therapy can provide the necessary exercise program to help prevent falls.
❌ Addition of a second antihypertensive medication:
Incorrect: This patient has a mildly elevated blood pressure on hydrochlorothiazide. It would be more appropriate to perform serial blood pressure measurements prior to prescribing additional antihypertensive medications.
❌ Low dose computed tomography (CT) chest imaging:
Incorrect: Low dose CT-chest imaging for lung cancer screening is indicated in patients up to age 80 who have a 20-pack-year smoking history and are currently smoking or have quit smoking within the last 15 years. This patient does not meet criteria for chest CT screening for lung cancer.
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Despite this patient's family history, a screening abdominal ultrasound for aortic aneurysm is not indicated. Screening for abdominal aortic ultrasound is indicated for biological males with a tobacco history who are between the ages of 65 and 75.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine follow-up visit. The patient is on several medications for the management of hypertension and osteoarthritis. Which of the following statements is true regarding medication pharmacokinetics in elderly patients?

choices.text: Decreased phase I hepatic metabolism of drugs
Increased renal excretion of water-soluble drugs
Decreased volume of distribution for lipid-soluble drugs
Increased gastrointestinal absorption of orally ingested drugs
Increased volume of distribution for water-soluble drugs

questions.solution:
As individuals age, there are associated changes in the pharmacokinetics of drug absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion. For instance, phase I hepatic metabolism is dampened with age. Therefore, drugs that are metabolized during phase II (e.g. lorazepam) should be preferred to those that are metabolized during phase I (e.g. diazepam). If the latter is needed, decreased therapeutic doses may suffice in the elderly.    

Other age-related changes in pharmacokinetics are shown in the following table:  



Option Analysis

✅ Decreased phase I hepatic metabolism of drugs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased renal excretion of water-soluble drugs:
Incorrect: Elderly individuals have a reduced glomerular filtration rate and reduced tubular excretion. As a result, renal excretion of water-soluble drugs is decreased.   
❌ Decreased volume of distribution for lipid-soluble drugs:
Incorrect: Elderly individuals have greater body fat content than younger individuals. The volume of distribution for lipid-soluble drugs will be increased, not decreased.  
❌ Increased gastrointestinal absorption of orally ingested drugs  :
Incorrect: Aging leads to reduced gastric acid secretion, splanchnic blood flow, and absorptive capacity of the small intestines. As a result, the absorption of orally ingested medications will decrease with aging.  
❌ Increased volume of distribution for water-soluble drugs:
Incorrect: Elderly individuals have decreased total body water volume. The volume of distribution for water-soluble drugs will be decreased, not increased.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant boy is brought to the primary care office by his parents for a well-check. The parents have no concerns. The child was born vaginally at 40 weeks gestation and weighed 8 lb, 1 oz. There is no family history of developmental delays. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 152/min, respiratory rate is 44/min, weight is in the 70<sup>th</sup> percentile, length is 64<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is 70<sup>th</sup> percentile. On examination, the baby is crying on the exam table with his mother standing next to him attempting to console him. Which of the following findings would be concerning in this patient?

choices.text: Holds fisted hands near the face most of the time
Inability to lift chest in tummy time
Inability to focus on an object three feet away

questions.solution:
This one-month-old infant is expected to startle at a loud sound, making it concerning if there is no response to loud sounds. Startling to loud sounds is considered a part of the language development of an infant, and also provides information about hearing status.

The developmental milestone assessment of an infant begins with a thorough history and physical examination. History-taking should begin with the birth history, including gestational age and birth weight, as well as whether there is a family history of developmental delays. Caregivers should be asked to provide details about what new skills their baby has learned since the last clinic visit, as well as whether they have any concerns about the child’s development. Important aspects to include in the history of a one-month-old infant include how the child is feeding and moving, and whether the infant responds to loud noises and can focus on an object placed a few inches from his or her face. If any of these areas are not met, or the child is not feeding well and gaining weight appropriately, it would be considered a red flag.

Typical physical examination findings for a one-month-old include lifting the head off of the exam table when placed prone, moving both arms and legs equally, and keeping the hands fisted and near the face most of the time. Young infants have a “startle” reflex known as the Moro reflex, where sudden movements, loud sounds, or a dropping feeling cause the baby to throw back his or her head, extend out the arms and legs, cry, and then pull the arms and legs back in (image below). Another important aspect to consider during an infant assessment, especially for very young infants, is to take note of any caregiver indifference, meaning a caregiver who is not responsive to their infant. Caregiver indifference is a red flag and should be investigated further.
 

 Moro Reflex by tawamie is licensed CC BY-SA 3.0 DEED Reproduced from WikimediaCommons  

Option Analysis

✅ No response to loud sounds:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Moro reflex is present:
Incorrect: The Moro or “startle” reflex is present from birth until around 2-6 months of age.  It would not be concerning for a one-month-old to still have a Moro reflex.  
❌ Holds fisted hands near the face most of the time:
Incorrect: Holding fisted hands near the face most of the time is expected for a one-month-old.  This will typically decrease to about 50% of the time by two months old and further decrease after that.  
❌ Inability to lift chest in tummy time:
Incorrect: A one-month-old is expected to be able to lift their head during tummy time, but an infant typically cannot lift the chest until two months of age.  
❌ Inability to focus on an object three feet away:
Incorrect: A one-month-old infant should be able to focus on an object placed a few inches from his or her face.  Infants begin to track objects and focus on objects further away after two months of age.

questions.text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the primary care office by her parents for a well-child visit. The child’s parents have no concerns. She eats a variety of healthy foods and rarely consumes high-sugar drinks. Since the last visit, she has begun showing more affection towards caregivers and following one-step directions. The child was born vaginally at 41 weeks of gestation and weighed 7 lb, 14 oz. There is no family history of developmental delays. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, weight is in the 60th percentile, height is in the 54th percentile, and head circumference is in the 74th percentile. On physical examination, the child is alert and playful. Which of the following findings would indicate the need for further evaluation?

choices.text: Using a raking grasp to pick up small objects
Inability to drink from an open cup

questions.solution:
This 15-month-old child presenting for a well-child visit should be evaluated for developmental milestones, including fine motor development. A child should typically start changing from a raking grasp to a pincer grasp (see image below) to pick up small objects around the age of 9-12 months. Inability to use the pincer grasp by the age of 15 months is a red flag and should prompt further evaluation.        

The developmental milestone assessment of a toddler begins with a thorough history and physical examination. History-taking should begin with the birth history, including gestational age and birth weight, as prematurity and low birth weight are associated with developmental delays. Some developmental delays have a genetic component; therefore, the interview should also include whether there is a family history of developmental delays. Caregivers should be asked to provide details about what new skills their child has learned since the last clinic visit, as well as whether they have any concerns about the child’s development. Important aspects to include in the developmental milestone assessment of a toddler include how the child is walking and running, how many blocks the child can stack, how they relate to their toys, ability to show empathy and affection, how many steps of direction the child can follow and how many words they can say.        

The physical examination portion of a developmental milestone assessment for a toddler should include an assessment of reflexes, muscle tone, and the child’s balance, as well as measurement of height, weight, and head circumference. Observation of how the child interacts with the caregiver and physician can also help provide valuable information on the child’s development.    



Option Analysis

✅  Using a raking grasp to pick up small objects:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Using 3 to 5 words:
Incorrect: A 15-month-old child is expected to have a vocabulary of around 3 to 5 words; this would not represent a red flag indicating the need for further evaluation.  
❌ Running stiff-legged:
Incorrect: Running stiff-legged is expected for a 15-month-old.  This should change to running well by age 18 to 24 months. 
❌ Inability to drink from an open cup :
Incorrect: Although many children will start to learn to drink from an open cup by 15 months of age, it is not concerning if a child has not. Typically, this skill is developed between the ages of 18 and 36 months. Therefore, this child would not require further evaluation at this time.  
❌  Inability to kick a ball :
Incorrect: The gross-motor skill of kicking a ball is expected to develop by the age of 24 months; therefore, the inability to do this would not be a concern in this 15-month-old child.

questions.text: A 30-month-old girl is brought to the pediatric office by her parents for a well-child visit. The parents are concerned that the child appears to stumble when trying to run. She can walk, kick a ball, and throw overhead. Since the last visit, she has started matching shapes and colors and using the pronouns “you” and “I.” The child was born vaginally at 40 weeks of gestation and weighed 8 lb, 2 oz. There is no family history of developmental delays. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, weight is in the 67th percentile, length is in the 62nd percentile and head circumference is in the 58th percentile. On examination, the child is playful and interactive. She answers questions using multi-word sentences and follows a two-step command.  She easily walks across the exam room with a broad gait but stumbles when attempting to go faster. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure the parents and recheck at 36 months

questions.solution:
This child has a red flag for a gross motor delay as she cannot run well at the age of 30 months. The first step in evaluating this child with a red flag for a developmental delay is to administer an age-appropriate developmental screening tool to assess and document the child’s development. The Ages and Stages Questionnaire is a developmental screening tool commonly used by healthcare professionals to provide a standardized assessment of a child’s developmental progress.        

Age-appropriate developmental screening tools can be used to assess and document gross motor, fine motor, cognitive, social-emotional, and language development. The typical format of a developmental questionnaire is to list specific activities and ask a parent to answer whether the child can perform that activity, using a scale such as “yes,” “sometimes,” or “not yet” for their answer options. Point values are then assigned to each of these answers. The total number of points in each developmental category can help identify whether there is a deficit in that area.        

A referral for a developmental and behavioral evaluation may be indicated depending on the nature of the deficit and results of the developmental screening tool. It should be confirmed that the child’s hearing and vision screenings are up-to-date, as deficits in these areas can significantly impact developmental milestones. Timely implementation of interventions is key to helping prevent long-term deficits and further developmental delays. Services available for early intervention include speech-language, physical, and occupational therapy.    

Option Analysis

✅ Administer the Ages & Stages Questionnaire:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Refer for a vision evaluation:
Incorrect: A vision deficit can lead to developmental delays, including motor development delays. A detailed vision assessment may be indicated later in the workup. However, the first step in assessing this child is to administer an age-appropriate developmental screening tool to assess and document the child’s developmental status.  
❌ Recommend sturdy shoes:
Incorrect: A 30-month-old child should be able to run well while barefoot. A change in footwear is unlikely to help her condition, and it would still be a developmental red flag if she could not run well without shoes. An age-appropriate developmental screening tool should be administered to assess and document the child’s developmental status. 
❌ Begin physical therapy:
Incorrect: This child with a red flag for gross motor delay may need physical therapy to help her learn to run; however, she has not yet had an adequate evaluation with a detailed age-appropriate developmental screening tool. 
❌ Reassure the parents and recheck at 36 months:
Incorrect: This child has a red flag for a gross motor delay as she is not yet able to run well at the age of 30 months. Failure to recognize a developmental delay and intervene promptly places the child at risk for long-term disability and additional delays.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician for a well-child visit. She recently started preschool and the parents are concerned that her development is slightly delayed compared to her peers. She was born at 38 weeks, weighing 7lbs 2oz. There is no family history of developmental delay. Today, she is 12th percentile for weight and 18th percentile for height. In the office, she is well-appearing with no focal findings. She spends most of the visit scribbling in a notebook and is cooperative for her physical examination. Her vision screen is normal. Which of the following represents the developmental milestones expected for this child?

choices.text: Gross Motor     Fine Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Hops on one foot   Holds pencil properly Washes hands Enjoys group play Tells stories
Gross Motor     Fine Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Skips    Draws triangles Dresses independently Follows rules during games Writes first name
Gross Motor     Fine Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Broad jumps   Cuts with scissors Knows right and left Apologizes for mistakes Reads 25 words

questions.solution:
This 3-year-old patient would be expected to walk upstairs with alternating feet, draw circles, eat independently, point to self in pictures, and use 3-word sentences. These are examples of age-appropriate developmental milestones in the 5 areas of developmental assessment: gross motor, fine motor, cognitive, social-emotional, and language.    

Evaluation of developmental milestones is performed at all well-child visits before the start of Kindergarten. When evaluating a patient for potential developmental delays, it is important to obtain a focused history and physical. Although the history of prematurity and lower birth weight are associated with developmental delays, these children are expected to have developmentally caught up with their peers by the age of 2 or 3. Inherited disorders can be associated with developmental delays, so evaluation should include asking about family history, specifically developmental delays and genetic disorders.        

Parents and caregivers spend a lot of time with their children and are an important resource when evaluating development. These adults can comment on the progression of milestones since the prior well-child visit. If they are concerned about development, it is important to investigate further.        

On physical examination, providers should observe how the patient interacts with others and the environment. A patient who doesn’t make eye contact or is unusually fearful or shy may warrant further evaluation. A thorough musculoskeletal and neurological examination should be performed specifically, looking at strength, tone, balance, and reflexes. If there is concern for language delay, a thorough evaluation of ears and mouth is recommended. Depending on the age of the patient, a hearing and vision screen should also be performed.   

Option Analysis

✅  Gross Motor     Fine Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Walks up stairs alternating feet     Draws circles     Eats independently     Points to self in picture     Uses 3-word sentences    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Gross Motor     Fine Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Hops on one foot   Holds pencil properly Washes hands Enjoys group play Tells stories :
Incorrect: These are expected milestones for a 4-year-old. This patient is 3-years-old and does not yet have these skills. 
❌  Gross Motor     Fine Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Skips    Draws triangles Dresses independently Follows rules during games Writes first name :
Incorrect: These are expected milestones for a 5-year-old. This patient is 3-years-old and does not yet have these skills. 
❌  Gross Motor     Fine Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Gallops    Ties a knot Uses a fork Has a favorite friend 100% intelligible :
Incorrect: These are expected milestones for a 4-year-old. This patient is 3-years-old and does not yet have these skills. 
❌  Gross Motor     Fine Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Broad jumps   Cuts with scissors Knows right and left Apologizes for mistakes Reads 25 words :
Incorrect: These are expected milestones for a 5-year-old. This patient is 3-years-old and does not yet have these skills.

questions.text: A one-month-old infant boy presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. Since birth, the baby has been doing well. The parent has no concerns and reports that the infant is tolerating breast milk without issue. He has had no illnesses, including fevers, cough, or congestion. The parent also notes that the infant has been looking at faces and fixates on and follows the parent while feeding. The infant was born full term without complications. Vital signs are within normal limits, and the patient has been gaining weight appropriately. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing male infant in no acute distress. The fontanelles are soft. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Hip exam demonstrates negative Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers. Genitourinary examination shows bilaterally descended testes. The baby moves all extremities symmetrically and has normal muscle tone. Which of the following additional findings would be expected on this patient's assessment?
questions.solution:
This one-month-old infant presents for a routine well-child visit. At this age, an expected developmental milestone is voice recognition. Infants should be alert and responsive, enjoy looking at faces, and recognize familiar voices.

Well-child visits promote the health and well-being of children from birth through adolescence. In the first year of life, each visit begins with a comprehensive history and physical exam, followed by age-specific interventions and recommendations.

Key history elements include birth history (including gestation age, birth weight, and any complications), interval history (noting any changes since the last visit), developmental milestones, caregiver concerns, social determinants of health (e.g., tobacco exposure, intimate partner violence, food insecurity), and protective factors (e.g. social support). The physical exam should include general appearance, growth measurements, and a full body evaluation with attention to fontanelles, head shape, red reflex, and muscle tone.

Infants should receive age-appropriate screenings and immunizations, and caregivers should receive guidance on nutrition and oral health, as well as anticipatory guidance.

Option Analysis

❌ Babbling :
Incorrect: Babbling typically begins around six months of age. Voice recognition is more likely at one month.
✅ Familiar voice recognition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rolling over:
Incorrect: Patients should be able to roll by four to six months of age. Voice recognition is more likely at one month.
❌ Crawling:
Incorrect: Patients are generally able to crawl by nine months of age. Voice recognition is more likely at one month.
❌ Smiling at own reflection:
Incorrect: Smiling at one’s own reflection typically occurs around 6 months of age. Voice recognition is more likely at one month.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the primary care office by her parents for a well-check visit. The parents are concerned that the child cannot stand yet. She can crawl and sit, turn her head to voices, and share interest in activities. She waves “bye-bye” and says “mama and dada” with meaning. The child was born vaginally at 40 weeks gestation and weighed 7 lb, 9 oz. There is no family history of developmental delays. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, weight is in the 57<sup>th</sup> percentile, length is 52<sup>nd</sup> percentile, and head circumference is in the 48<sup>th</sup> percentile. On examination, the child is playful and interactive. She can move both arms and legs freely against gravity and resistance, and range of motion is intact.  She is not able to stand alone or with her hands held. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure the parents and recheck at 18 months

questions.solution:
This child has a red flag for a gross motor delay as she cannot stand at the age of 12 months.  The first step in evaluating a child with a red flag for a developmental delay is to administer an age-appropriate developmental screening tool to assess and document the child’s development. The Ages and Stages Questionnaire is a developmental screening tool commonly used by healthcare professionals to provide a standardized assessment of a child’s developmental progress.

When a developmental red flag is identified during an infant’s developmental milestone assessment, an age-appropriate developmental screening tool should be used to further qualify the deficit and provide a standardized assessment of the child’s development status.  These tools typically assess the full range of a child’s development, since many areas are interrelated. The areas assessed include gross motor, fine motor, cognitive, social-emotional, and language development. A referral for a diagnostic evaluation of the child’s development may be indicated. Visual-motor tests and auditory milestone scales can be used to further assess for deficits. Timely implementation of interventions is key to helping prevent long-term deficits and further developmental delays. Services available for early intervention include speech-language, physical, and occupational therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer the Ages & Stages Questionnaire:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Refer for a hearing evaluation:
Incorrect: A hearing deficit can lead to developmental delays, especially in the areas of receptive and expressive communication. This child’s language and response to caregivers is developing as expected, making a significant hearing deficit that needs to be evaluated less likely.  
❌ Refer to an orthopedic specialist  :
Incorrect: An orthopedic specialist may be needed when developmental delays are caused by an anatomic abnormality. Although an underlying anatomic abnormality is possible in this patient, she has a normal physical examination and otherwise has expected strength and use of her legs, making a more detailed assessment with an age-appropriate developmental screening tool the best next step.  
❌ Begin physical therapy:
Incorrect: This child with a red flag for gross motor delay may need physical therapy to help her learn to stand and walk; however, she has not yet had an adequate evaluation with a detailed age-appropriate developmental screening tool.  
❌ Reassure the parents and recheck at 18 months:
Incorrect: This child has a red flag for a gross motor delay as she is not yet able to stand at the age of 12 months. Failure to recognize a developmental delay and intervene in a timely manner places children at risk for long-term disability and additional delays.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the pediatric office for a well-check visit. The parents have no concerns, and there were no changes to her health since the last visit. She eats a variety of foods, including fruits, vegetables, meat, and fish regularly. She rarely consumes sugary drinks. She has good sleeping habits. Recommended vaccinations prior to this visit are up-to-date. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 98/60 mmHg, weight is in the 56th percentile, and height is in the 62nd percentile. On physical examination, she is a pleasant and alert child. She makes good eye contact while talking and answers questions appropriately. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Tanner Stage 1 sexual maturity is observed. Which of the following is most appropriate to include at this visit?

choices.text: Lipid panel  HPV vaccine discussion  Gender and sexuality discussion  Mental health discussion
HPV vaccine discussion  Lead level  Mental health discussion  Influenza vaccination
Meningococcal vaccination  Lead level  Influenza vaccination  Gender and sexuality discussion
Lipid panel  HPV vaccine discussion  Meningococcal vaccination  Review of academic performance
HPV vaccine discussion  DTap vaccination  Discussion of mental health  Review of academic performance

questions.solution:
The well-check visit for a 9-year-old child should include a screening lipid panel, HPV vaccination counseling, review of academic performance, and discussion of mental health and gender and sexuality. Influenza and COVID-19 vaccinations should be offered based on the season.    

The well-child visit is an opportunity for healthcare providers to engage with patients and their caregivers about a number of components of health promotion, including routine screenings, immunizations, family wellness, child development, and safety. The details of each component will vary depending on the age of the child. Around the age of 7-8 years old, children should begin having a yearly assessment of their sexual maturity as characterized by the Tanner stage. This is also when discussions regarding early signs of puberty can begin and caregivers can be encouraged to talk with their children about body changes that can be expected. Starting at age 9-10 years old discussions regarding gender identity and sexuality can begin. Families should be encouraged to talk openly with their child about values, identity, and self-expression and to welcome questions as their child matures.  

Around age 7 and at subsequent visits, the well-child visit should include an assessment of the child’s mental health. Families should be encouraged to promote mental health and well-being by frequently checking in with their child and helping their child recognize, process, and effectively express strong emotions. Safety should be reviewed at every well-child visit, including seatbelt use, helmet use, sun protection, internet safety, bullying, and safe firearm storage.

Option Analysis

✅  Lipid panel  HPV vaccine discussion  Gender and sexuality discussion  Mental health discussion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  HPV vaccine discussion  Lead level  Mental health discussion  Influenza vaccination :
Incorrect: HPV vaccine discussion, discussion of mental health, and influenza vaccination if seasonally appropriate would be appropriate at a 9-year-old well-check. However, a lead level is typically checked twice by the age of 2 years and then is not routinely checked after that. 
❌  Meningococcal vaccination  Lead level  Influenza vaccination  Gender and sexuality discussion :
Incorrect: Seasonal influenza vaccination and discussion of gender and sexuality are appropriate for a 9-year-old well-check. However, a lead level is typically checked twice by the age of 2 years and then is not routinely checked after that. Also, the meningococcal vaccine is not routinely offered until the 11- or 12-year-old visit. 
❌  Lipid panel  HPV vaccine discussion  Meningococcal vaccination  Review of academic performance  :
Incorrect: A lipid panel, HPV vaccine discussion, and review of academic performance would be appropriate for a 9-year-old well-check. However, the meningococcal vaccine is not routinely offered until the 11- or 12-year-old visit. 
❌  HPV vaccine discussion  DTap vaccination  Discussion of mental health  Review of academic performance :
Incorrect: The HPV vaccine discussion, discussion of mental health, and review of academic performance would be appropriate at a 9-year-old well-check. However, the DTap vaccine is usually given last between the ages of 4 and 6 years old. A Tdap vaccine can be given to an older child who needs a catch-up vaccine, but this child is noted to be up-to-date on previously recommended vaccinations.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a well child visit. Parents report that he is doing well in preschool, but they have concerns regarding his language development. He has over 200 words but only speaks in two-word phrases. There are no concerns regarding his receptive language. He was born at 36 weeks, weighing 5lbs 8oz. He has no significant past medical history. There is no family history of developmental delay. Today, he is 46th percentile for weight and 60th percentile for height. Vitals are appropriate for age. On physical examination, he is well-appearing. Tympanic membranes are pearly gray with normal light reflex and no loss of landmarks. Oropharyngeal examination is normal with no apparent ankyloglossia. Which of the following is the best next step in his evaluation?

choices.text: Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers - Revised (MCHAT-R)
Re-evaluation at 4 year well child visit

questions.solution:
This patient presents with concern for a language developmental delay, specifically the inability to use three word phrases, which is a developmental red flag in a child who is 3-years-old. The first step in evaluation is to administer an age-appropriate developmental screening tool to more carefully assess development.        

Examples of age-appropriate developmental screening tools include the Ages and Stages Questionnaire (ASQ) and Parents’ Evaluation of Developmental Status (PEDS). These more detailed assessments will identify children who require early intervention. Early intervention typically involves thorough evaluation by therapists (physical, occupational, and speech) to determine if patients would benefit from services. If a child qualifies, therapy sessions are initiated.       

Depending on the results of the age-specific developmental assessments, a physician may consider hearing and vision screens as well as a referral to a developmental and behavioral pediatrician. On the other hand, if no developmental red flags are identified using the screening tools and development is progressing appropriately, reassurance and anticipatory guidance can be provided to the parents, and the patient can be re-evaluated at the next scheduled developmental assessment.   

Option Analysis

✅ Age-specific developmental screening tool:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers - Revised (MCHAT-R):
Incorrect: Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers - Revised (MCHAT-R) is a developmental screening tool that assesses risk of autism spectrum disorders. The MCHAT-R is valid for screening children ages 16-30 months. An isolated communication delay is not concerning for an autism spectrum delay. Additionally, this patient is too old to be evaluated by MCHAT-R. 
❌ Re-evaluation at 4 year well child visit:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a developmental red flag. A 3-year-old should be speaking in three-word phrases at this age. This patient requires further evaluation with an age-specific developmental screening tool before his next well child visit. 
❌ Hearing evaluation:
Incorrect: A hearing evaluation is often part of the evaluation when there is a language delay. However, this patient requires further developmental screening first. Since there are no concerns regarding receptive language, a hearing evaluation would not be the best next step in evaluation. 
❌ Referral to Developmental Pediatrician:
Incorrect: Developmental pediatricians will often evaluate patients with developmental delays, but referral should not occur before an age-specific developmental tool is used.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant boy is brought to the primary care office by his parents for a well-check. The parents have no concerns. The child was born vaginally at 39 weeks gestation and weighed 8 lb, 3 oz. There is no family history of developmental delays. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, weight is in the 67<sup>th</sup> percentile, length is 62<sup>nd</sup> percentile, and head circumference is in the 58<sup>th</sup> percentile. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing, playful infant, and exam findings are within normal limits. Caregivers are appropriately engaged. Which of the following best represents the developmental milestones that are expected to be present for this infant?
questions.solution:
This six-month-old infant is expected to be able to sit in a tripod position, bang and shake toys, know familiar people and display stranger anxiety, as well as recognize their own name. Additional developmental milestones for a six-month-old include transferring objects between hands, using a raking grasp, interacting with a mirror, babbling and understanding the word “no”.

The developmental milestones of an infant are assessed regularly throughout the first year of the child’s life.  These milestones are functional skills that follow a predictable sequence by specific ages, and are divided into five major categories: gross motor development, which relates to the movement of large muscles; fine motor development, which relates to the movement of small muscles; cognitive development, which covers reasoning, memory, and problem-solving; social-emotional development, which describes attachment to and interactions with others; and finally, language development, which covers both receptive and expressive communication. Significant deviations from the expected skills are referred to as red flags, which should be further investigated.
 
Developmental Red Flags by Age 

 Birth 
  •  Prematurity 
  •  Low birth weight 
 1 month 
  •  Poor feeding/movement due to low muscle tone 
  •  Does not respond to loud sounds 
  •  Does not focus on objects a few inches from face 
 2 months 
  •  Cannot lift head during tummy time 
  •  Does not look at faces or respond to voices 
 4 months 
  •  Unable to bring hands to midline 
  •  Not smiling or vocalizing 
 6 months 
  •  Unable to sit or transfer objects between hands 
  •  Does not turn toward voices, smile, or laugh 
 9 months 
  •  Unable to sit or roll 
  •  Does not babble or engage in back-and-forth communication 
 12 months 
  •  Does not stand 
  •  Does not respond to name 
  •  Indifferent to caregiver 
 All ages 
  • Caregiver indifference 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These are the developmental milestones expected of a 2-month-old.  If a 6-month-old infant was only able to do these activities, it would be a red flag.   
❌ :
Incorrect:  These are the developmental milestones expected of a 4-month-old.  If a 6-month-old infant was only able to do these activities, it would be a red flag.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These are the developmental milestones expected of a 9-month-old.  A 6-month-old infant may be able to achieve some of these milestones, but it would not be a red flag if they did not.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These are the developmental milestones expected of a 12-month-old.  A 6-month-old infant likely cannot achieve these milestones, which would be expected for their age and not represent a red flag.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the primary care office by his parents for a well-child visit. The patient’s parents have no specific concerns. He eats a variety of healthy foods regularly and rarely consumes high-sugar drinks. He has good sleeping habits. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, weight is in the 70th percentile, height is 64th percentile, and head circumference is in the 70th percentile. On physical examination, the child is alert and playful. Which of the following findings would indicate the need for further evaluation?

choices.text: Inability to carry a toy while walking
Caregivers are able to understand less than half of the child’s speech
Rigidity with routines and frequent temper tantrums
Genu varum orientation of the legs

questions.solution:
This 18-month-old child presenting for a well-child visit should be evaluated for developmental milestones, including gross motor development. By 18 months of age, children should be able to walk independently and carry a toy while walking. Lack of this ability should prompt further evaluation.  

The well-child visit for a toddler begins with a comprehensive history, including the birth history and discussion of any health changes since the last examination. Caregivers should be asked to provide details about the new skills their child has learned since the last clinic visit as well as whether they have any concerns about the child’s development. Important aspects to include in the history of an 18-month-old child include how the child is eating and sleeping; whether the child can walk independently and carry toys while walking; whether the child is beginning to use a cup and spoon; and aspects of play, such as the ability to engage in pretend play. It is recommended that toddlers receive screening for autism at 18 and 24 months using a validated screening questionnaire or checklist, such as the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers, Revised (M-CHAT-R).   

The physical examination at a well-child visit for a toddler includes a general assessment of how the child interacts with the healthcare provider and the caregiver(s), including aspects such as making eye contact and turning to look at an adult when something new happens. A comprehensive physical examination should also be performed. The hepatitis A vaccine is often administered at the 18-month well-check as it is recommended to be given initially at age 12-23 months with a second dose at least six months after the first dose. Genu varum orientation of the legs is a normal finding in children up to age 18-24 months.  



Option Analysis

✅ Inability to carry a toy while walking:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caregivers are able to understand less than half of the child’s speech:
Incorrect: It would be expected that by age 24 months, adults would be able to understand about half of the child’s speech. This child is only 18 months of age, and it is not concerning that caregivers are not able to understand most of his speech yet; a red flag would be if the child could not say approximately 10-20 words. 
❌ Rigidity with routines and frequent temper tantrums:
Incorrect: Rigidity with routines in children beyond the age of four can be concerning for autism; however, children aged 18-24 months are commonly rigid in routines and are prone to temper tantrums. Although parents may need counseling regarding how to best manage the behaviors, this would be considered expected behavior for this child. 
❌ Inability to jump:
Incorrect: Children are expected to be able to jump by 24-30 months of age. This child is only 18 months of age; it would be expected that the child be able to walk independently and do some running but not jumping. 
❌ Genu varum orientation of the legs:
Incorrect: Genu varum or “bowleg” orientation of the lower extremities is common in infants and toddlers and typically resolves around 18-24 months of age. See image in Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 24-month-old child is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for a well-check. The parents have no concerns. The child was born vaginally at 39 weeks of gestation and weighed 9 lb, 3 oz. There is no family history of developmental delays. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, weight is in the 47th percentile, length is in the 52nd percentile, and head circumference is in the 46th percentile. Physical examination shows a well-appearing and playful child, and exam findings are within normal limits. Which of the following best represents the developmental milestones that are expected to be present for this child?

choices.text: Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Crawls up stairs   Turns pages in board book Shows empathy Vocabulary of 3 to 5 words
Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Sits in chair   Matches pairs of objects Imitates peers Vocabulary of 10-25 words
Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Jumps    Matches shapes and colors Follows simple routines Uses pronouns such as I, me, you, we
Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Pulls to stand   Understands cause and effect (push a button for toy to pop up) Plays peek-a-boo Waves bye-bye

questions.solution:
This 24-month-old child is expected to be able to throw overhead, engage in simple pretend play, display social referencing, and have a vocabulary of more than 50 words. Social referencing refers to when a child looks to their caregiver for cues about how to respond in new situations. Additional developmental milestones for a 24-month-old child include walking up and down stairs, kicking a ball, drawing lines and circles, solving simple puzzles, undressing themselves, engaging in parallel play, making a two-word sentence, and referring to self by name.        

Developmental milestones are behaviors and functional skills that children are expected to acquire by a specific age. These milestones are typically achieved in a predictable sequence and are divided into five major categories:    
  •  Gross motor development, which relates to the movement of large muscles and fine motor development, which relates to the movement of small muscles  
  •  Cognitive development, which includes reasoning, memory, and problem-solving  
  •  Social-emotional development, which describes attachment to and interactions with others  
  •  Language development, which consists of receptive and expressive communication.  
     
When a child has not met certain milestones by a given age, it is considered a red flag and should prompt further assessment.    



Option Analysis

✅  Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Throws overhead     Simple pretend play     Social referencing     Vocabulary of more than 50 words    :
Correct:  See Main Explanation. 
❌  Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Crawls up stairs   Turns pages in board book Shows empathy Vocabulary of 3 to 5 words :
Incorrect: These are the expected milestones for a 15-month-old child. A 24-month-old should be able to walk up and down steps and have advanced beyond the noted activities.  
❌  Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Sits in chair   Matches pairs of objects Imitates peers Vocabulary of 10-25 words :
Incorrect: These are the expected milestones for an 18-month-old child. A 24-month-old should be able to do these and also have advanced to the next milestones.  
❌  Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Jumps    Matches shapes and colors Follows simple routines Uses pronouns such as I, me, you, we :
Incorrect: This represents the milestones of a 30-month-old child.  A 24-month-old would not yet be expected to be able to do these things.  
❌  Motor     Cognitive     Social-Emotional     Language     Pulls to stand   Understands cause and effect (push a button for toy to pop up) Plays peek-a-boo Waves bye-bye :
Incorrect:  These are the expected milestones for a 12-month-old child. A 24-month-old should be able to get to a standing position on their own and should be able to do the noted activities, but also have advanced beyond them.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for her well-child visit. She was born full-term, weighing 7lbs 8oz. Her only significant past medical history is intermittent asthma which is treated with albuterol as needed. There is no family history of developmental delay. Today, she is 30th percentile for weight and 45th percentile for height. Vitals are appropriate for age. On physical examination, she is well-appearing and has normal musculoskeletal and neurologic exams. Which of the following would be a developmental red flag for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for her 4-year-old well-child visit. At this age, it would be a red flag indicating a possible developmental delay if the patient was unable to jump in place. Other red flags at this age include inability to answer simple questions, unclear speech, lack of pronoun use, and ignoring other children.        

At each well visit, 5 areas of development are evaluated: gross motor, fine motor, cognitive, social-emotional, and language. It is important to assess milestones in each of these categories. Assessment is done through caregiver reports, direct observation, and often with the use of age-appropriate developmental screening tools such as the Ages and Stages Questionnaire (ASQ). Below are examples of age-appropriate developmental milestones:  



After evaluation with an age-appropriate developmental screening tool, patients with developmental red flags should be referred to a specialist such as a therapist and/or a developmental and behavioral pediatrician. Red flags for developmental delay in 3-year-olds include difficulty using stairs, inability to form three-word sentences and lack of pretend play. Red flags for 5-year-olds include poor balance, inability to draw a square, resisting daily tasks, not knowing shapes/letters/colors, inability to distinguish between real and imaginary, and unusually fearful/sad/shy/angry. 

Option Analysis

✅ Inability to jump in place:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inability to draw a triangle:
Incorrect: A child should be able to draw a triangle at 5-years-old and be able to draw a square and an “X” at 4-years-old.  
❌ Inability to dress independently:
Incorrect: A child should be able to dress independently at 5-years-old. 
❌ Inability to answer “why” questions:
 Ability to speak using 400 wordsA child should be able to answer “why” questions at 5-years-old. 
❌ Ability to speak using 400 words:
Incorrect: A child should have 300-1000 words at 4-years-old.

questions.text: A six-month-old infant boy is brought to pediatrician for a well-child visit. The patient was born full term and has had only one mild upper respiratory infection since the 4-month check. The caregiver for the infant notes that he has been rolling, laughing, and tolerating fortified breast milk without issue. Vital signs are within normal limits, and weight is appropriate. On physical examination, the infant appears well and is in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Genitourinary exam reveals normally descended testes. The infant moves all extremities symmetrically and has normal muscle tone. After administering age-appropriate vaccinations, the pediatrician begins health promotion counseling. Which of the following components of health promotion is indicated during this visit?

choices.text: Scheduling a first visit to the dentist

questions.solution:
A six-month-old infant presents for a routine well-child visit. Nutrition in the first year typically includes formula and/or breastfeeding, with the introduction of solid foods. The consistency of foods varies by age, with mashed or pureed foods introduced at six months and finger foods at nine months.

Well-child visits promote the health and well-being of children from birth through adolescence. In the first year, each visit begins with a comprehensive history and physical examination, followed by age-specific interventions and recommendations. Patients should also be provided with specific health promotion interventions based upon age.

Well-child visits occur 48-72 hours after discharge and at one, two, four, six, nine, and twelve months of age. At each visit, the infant should receive age-appropriate screenings, immunizations, and developmental assessments. Caregivers should be counseled on nutrition and oral health and provided with anticipatory guidance. The specific interventions for each component depend on the infant’s age.

At the 6-month visit, caregiver screening for depression should be conducted. Vaccinations should be offered, including hepatitis B, DTaP, pneumococcal conjugate, inactivated poliovirus, influenza, and COVID-19. An oral exam should be performed, and fluoride varnish may be applied to the teeth. Caregivers should be encouraged to continue cleaning the baby’s teeth with a soft cloth or toothbrush and a small amount of fluoridated toothpaste. Safety tips should be discussed, including car safety, home childproofing, and strategies for sun protection (e.g. sunscreen).

Option Analysis

❌ Introduction of whole milk:
Incorrect: Introduction of whole milk should take place at age 12 months. Given this patient's age, introduction of mashed and pureed solids is more appropriate.
✅ Introduction of pureed solid foods:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Scheduling a first visit to the dentist:
Incorrect: Patients do not require their first dental visit until 1 year of age. Patients at six months of age should have their teeth (if present) brushed with toothpaste and have an oral exam performed by their pediatrician.
❌ Lead level screening:
Incorrect: Universal lead level screening should occur at 12 months of age; earlier visits involve risk assessment but not routine testing. Given this patient's age, introduction of mashed and pureed solids is more appropriate.
❌ Hemoglobin and hematocrit screening:
Incorrect: Universal anemia screening (hemoglobin and hematocrit) is recommended at 12 months of age, unless a review of anemia risk factors warrants further investigation. Given this healthy patient's age, introduction of mashed and pureed solids is more appropriate.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic because her friend at school had infectious mononucleosis two weeks ago, and the patient wants to be tested. For the past three days, the patient has had a low-grade fever and a sore throat. She has not had a cough. She is not sexually active and does not use alcohol, tobacco, or other recreational substances. Temperature is 38.3 ºC (101.0 ºF), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min and blood pressure is 112/72 mmHg. On physical exam, there are multiple swollen tender lymph nodes in the anterior cervical chain bilaterally. The tonsils are erythematous, enlarged, and exudative.  Serum heterophile antibody and anti-EBV viral capsid IgM are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 18-year-old girl presents for evaluation of sore throat and low-grade fevers and is requesting testing for mononucleosis. The negative heterophile antibody and anti-EBV viral capsid IgM tests rule out infectious mononucleosis (IM). Based on the Centor Criteria, which is used to determine the need for testing for streptococcal pharyngitis, this patient has a score of 4 (age 15-44 yo, tonsillar exudates, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, absence of cough), and likely has streptococcal pharyngitis.    

IM and streptococcal pharyngitis can present similarly, though strep pharyngitis is more often associated with tender swollen lymphadenopathy in the anterior cervical chain, and symptoms of IM are more often prolonged. If IM is suspected, serum heterophile antibody testing should be performed. If this is positive, then IM is confirmed. However, it is common to have false negative results early in the disease course therefore If heterophile antibody testing is negative and IM is strongly suggested, a complete blood count and peripheral smear should be performed. If the absolute lymphocyte count >4000/mm3 OR >50% OR >10% atypical lymphocytes are seen on the peripheral smear, then anti-EBV viral capsid IgM testing should be performed; and if this is positive, then IM is confirmed. If the anti-EBV viral capsid IgM testing is negative, then a search for an alternative diagnosis should be pursued.   

Option Analysis

✅ Streptococcal pharyngitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Infectious mononucleosis:
Incorrect: While infectious mononucleosis is a common cause of sore throat and fever in this age group, the patient’s significant anterior cervical lymphadenopathy and negative serum testing suggest strep pharyngitis. 
❌ Epstein-Barr virus infection:
Incorrect: Immunocompetent/healthy young patients like this one who are infected with Epstein-Barr virus infection can develop infectious mononucleosis; however, given the negative testing and significant anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, streptococcal pharyngitis (“strep throat”) is more likely. 
❌ Primary cytomegalovirus infection:
Incorrect: In young healthy patients, primary cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is typically asymptomatic. CMV can lead to various infectious syndromes in immunocompromised patients like those who have had bone marrow or solid organ transplantation. 
❌ Lemierre syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Lemierre syndrome, a rare complication of bacterial pharyngitis, typically present with unilateral neck pain, swelling, and fever due to septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein. This patient does not show these findings or a prolonged course characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the urgent care clinic desiring testing for infectious mononucleosis. The patient’s girlfriend was diagnosed with mononucleosis last week. The patient has had a fever, fatigue, myalgias, and a mild sore throat for the past 2 days. past medical history is significant for severe peptic ulcer disease. Current medication includes lansoprazole and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the patient appears fatigued. Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and palatal petechiae are present along with erythematous enlarged tonsils bilaterally. Serum heterophile antibody is obtained and is negative. Peripheral smear shows >10% atypical lymphocytes And Anti-EBV viral capsid IgM is positive. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 17-year-old boy with recent exposure to infectious mononucleosis (IM) presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of this disease. Subsequent serum testing confirms the diagnosis of IM. Acetaminophen can be given as an antipyretic as part of supportive treatment.    

Patients with IM typically present with fever, fatigue, myalgias, and sore throat. On physical exam, patients may have tonsillar erythema and exudates, posterior cervical chain lymphadenopathy, and occasionally splenomegaly. Diagnosis of IM can be confirmed with a positive heterophile antibody or anti-EBV viral capsid IgM test.   

The treatment of IM is supportive. Patients should be counseled about the need for rest and adequate hydration. Patients should be treated with anti-pyrectics such as acetaminophen, and they may benefit from the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen). In this patient with severe peptic ulcer disease, the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories is contraindicated. Patients should also be counseled to avoid strenuous exercise or contact sports for three weeks given the risk of splenic rupture.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acetaminophen:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Repeat heterophile antibody testing:
Incorrect: The patient’s exposure history, physical examination, and IgM testing support a diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis. Repeating the heterophile antibody is not necessary currently. 
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: While nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are an appropriate supportive treatment for patients with infectious mononucleosis, this patient’s severe peptic ulcer disease makes this class of agents contraindicated. 
❌ Ganciclovir:
Incorrect: Ganciclovir is used to treat cytomegalovirus infections and certain severe Epstein-Barr virus infections such as viral hepatitis. It is not indicated for treatment of infectious mononucleosis. 
❌ Evaluate for an alternative diagnosis :
Incorrect: The patient’s exposure history, physical examination, and IgM testing all support infectious mononucleosis and the patient should be treated with supportive measures.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old Caucasian infant is brought to the pediatrician’s office by his parents for evaluation of failure to thrive and persistent frothy stools. He was born at term with no antenatal or delivery problems. His parents and older brother are all healthy. The patient is below the 10th percentile for both height and weight. Physical examination reveals that the patient has difficulty with balance and poor muscle coordination. In addition, the patient is found to have normal central vision but impaired peripheral vision. A peripheral smear is obtained, and the results are as follows:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most appropriate high-dose supplementation to prevent further neurologic deterioration in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has abetalipoproteinemia, an autosomal recessive condition characterized by a deficiency of both apolipoprotein B-48 and B-100 secondary to a MTTP gene mutation. Both of these proteins are necessary for normal fat absorption and chylomicron formation. As a result, patients with the condition have fat malabsorption and a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins.  

Symptoms manifest shortly after birth. Patients present with failure to thrive, muscle weakness, and steatorrhea. Absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) are also affected. Vitamin A deficiency can contribute to the development of retinitis pigmentosa. Persistent deficiency of vitamin E, a crucial substance for myelin formation and antioxidant properties, contributes to the development of spinocerebellar degeneration. Vitamin D deficiency can cause osteomalacia.  

Laboratory testing will reveal low serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels. Blood smears will reveal acanthocytes, abnormal red blood cells with a spiked membrane. Colonoscopy will show lipid-laden enterocytes. Genetic testing will confirm the presence of a MTTP gene mutation.  

Treatment is initiation of high-dose vitamin E supplementation and restriction of long-chain fatty acids;  limiting dietary fat reduces steatorrhea and facilitates absorption of other essential nutrients required for maintaining growth and development.  


Option Analysis

❌ Magnesium:
Incorrect: Magnesium is required for N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors, which prompt a calcium influx after stimulation with excitatory amino acids, such as glutamate. While hypomagnesemia may lead to severe neurological sequelae, it is not precipitated by fat malabsorption.  
❌ Omega-3 fatty acid  :
Incorrect: Long-chain fatty acids, such as omega-3, require ApoB-containing lipoproteins in order to be transported through the blood. In addition to nutritional supplementation, treatment of abetalipoproteinemia requires restriction of omega-3 fatty acid (and other long-chain fatty acids) since it can exacerbate steatorrhea and malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.   
❌ Vitamin A:
Incorrect: Vitamin A is required for the production of rhodopsin, a light-absorbing molecule. Rhodopsin is necessary for vision in low-light environments. Vitamin A is often malabsorbed in patients with abetalipoproteinemia and can cause visual deficits. However, vitamin A deficiency is not associated with neurological dysfunction.  
✅ Vitamin E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zinc:
Incorrect: Zinc is a cofactor for many of the body’s important enzymes. It is required for wound healing, connective tissue maintenance, and adequate growth. However, mineral absorption is typically not affected in patients with fat malabsorption.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department via ambulance after being found unconscious in a gas station parking lot. On arrival at the emergency department, the patient is obtunded and cannot provide a history. Temperature is 36.3 ºC (96.3 ºF), pulse is 48/min, blood pressure is 100/58 mmHg, respiratory rate is 10/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 88% on room air. On physical examination, needle marks are present on both upper extremities. The patient is given one dose of IV naloxone and immediately wakes up. After three minutes, the patient becomes lethargic and unresponsive. Repeat blood pressure is 106/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 12/min and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 92% on room air. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an opioid overdose as suggested by obtounded mental status, the presence of needle marks, and severe respiratory depression. This patient’s significant improvement after a one-time dose of naloxone also strongly indicates an overdose.

Patients with an opioid overdose should be given IV naloxone, a mu-opioid receptor antagonist, which can reverse the central nervous system effects of opioids. Naloxone has a short duration of action, often shorter than the causative opioid, so additional doses of IV naloxone may be required. In most cases, an infusion is warranted and should be continued until the patient’s mental status returns and remains at baseline. All patients with opioid intoxication or overdose should be referred for substance use counseling, and the use of a maintenance medication such as buprenorphine, methadone, or naltrexone should be strongly considered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Start naloxone infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start subcutaneous methylnaltrexone:
Incorrect: Methylnaltrexone is a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist. It is used for opioid-induced constipation. It does not reverse CNS effects of opioid overdose/intoxication and would not be of significant benefit.  
❌ Admit for observation:
Incorrect: This patient is incompletely treated and still at high risk for decompensation. Further treatment is still needed, so observation alone at this point is inappropriate.  
❌ Start oral naltrexone:
Incorrect: Naltrexone is used for treating chronic opioid use disorder rather than acute intoxication. In addition, this patient is extremely lethargic and cannot safely swallow pills, so IV medications should be used.  
❌ Consult psychiatry:
Incorrect: Mental health and substance abuse counseling should be involved in the treatment of any patients with opioid intoxication or overdose. At some facilities, the psychiatry team facilitates this. However, this patient has an incompletely treated overdose and needs to be medically treated before counseling is started.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter. The patient is a seasonal farmworker and was found lying down and minimally responsive under a tree. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. The patient is inconsistent in taking his home medications. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg. The patient's extremities are twitching on physical examination, and his clothing is soaked in urine. The patient is also drooling and coughs regularly. He is subsequently started on the appropriate treatment. This patient is at increased risk of developing which one of the following complications from this treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with symptoms of organophosphate poisoning (e.g., altered mental status, drooling, involuntary urination) and most likely received treatment with atropine for reversal of cholinergic symptoms. He is at increased risk of developing urinary retention due to a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia.  

Atropine is an antimuscarinic drug that can lead to several significant and potentially dangerous side effects. The medication can blockade thermoregulatory sweating and hyperthermia (also termed  atropine fever), especially in children and infants. Sweating, salivation, and lacrimation are all significantly reduced or stopped. Moderate tachycardia is common, and severe tachycardia or arrhythmias may develop with large overdoses.    

In elderly individuals, significant toxicities include acute angle-closure glaucoma (due to medication-induced mydriasis) and urinary retention, especially in men with prostatic hyperplasia. Constipation and blurred vision are common adverse effects in all age groups. Other adverse effects include dry mouth, flushed skin, dizziness, confusion, and delirium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Urinary retention:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Scleritis:
Incorrect: Scleritis is an inflammatory condition characterized by inflammation and redness of the sclera. Patients will experience severe eye pain and photophobia. Atropine exacerbates acute angle-closure glaucoma via pupil dilation, but not scleritis.  
❌ Migraine with aura:
Incorrect: Common precipitants for migraine with aura include caffeine, stress, and hormonal changes. Atropine is not known to precipitate migraines.  
❌ Flank pain with hematuria:
Incorrect: Patients who consume ethylene glycol, a common antifreeze component, can present with flank pain with hematuria secondary to renal stone formation. Although atropine can cause urinary retention, it does not precipitate stone formation in the kidneys.
❌ Respiratory depression:
Incorrect: Respiratory depression is a fatal side effect of benzodiazepine overdose. Atropine causes bronchodilation and is unlikely to affect the respiratory drive.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after losing consciousness at work. The patient is somnolent but responds to vocal stimuli. He recalls that over the last 12 hours, he has been experiencing muscle spasms, blurred vision, dry mouth, and hallucinations. The symptoms started after  eating some wild berries that he had picked during a camping trip. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals dry flushed skin and enlarged pupils. The bladder is palpable, and straight catheterization drains 450 mL of urine. Which of the following best describes the drug that can help reverse this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, blurred vision, dry mouth, flushed skin, and urinary retention. This constellation of symptoms suggests anticholinergic syndrome, likely due to intoxication from belladonna alkaloids in the wild berries. The central acetylcholinesterase inhibitor physostigmine can best treat the patient’s condition.  

Anticholinesterases, also termed indirect cholinomimetics, inhibit the enzyme acetylcholinesterase that typically degrades acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft. As a result, more acetylcholine molecules remain, causing increased and prolonged acetylcholine-mediated muscarinic and nicotinic effects. Examples of anticholinesterases include edrophonium, neostigmine, physostigmine, pyridostigmine, rivastigmine, galantamine, and donepezil.  



Option Analysis

❌ Centrally acting anticholinergic:
Incorrect: Benztropine is a centrally acting anticholinergic agent used to treat Parkinsonism. Given its anticholinergic properties, benztropine will most likely worsen this patient’s condition.  
❌ Centrally acting dopamine blocker:
Incorrect: Haloperidol is a centrally acting dopamine blocker used to treat psychosis. It has anticholinergic properties and will most likely worsen this patient’s condition.  
✅ Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ β1-adrenergic receptor blocker:
Incorrect: Metoprolol, a β1-adrenergic blocker, is used to treat angina, arrhythmias, and coronary artery disease. However, it would be ineffective in reversing this patient’s symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity.  
❌ μ-receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Naloxone is a μ-receptor blocker used as an antidote for opioid overdose. However, naloxone is ineffective in reversing anticholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found down outside. The patient is lethargic and cannot provide a history. On arrival, the patient’s temperature is 80 ºF (26.7 ºC), pulse is 36/min, respiratory rate is 6/min, blood pressure is 75/51 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 72% on room air. Serum potassium is 3.1 mEq/L, and serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL. Chest radiograph shows a dense right lower lobe infiltrate. Shortly after bloodwork is obtained, the patient becomes pulseless, and advanced cardiac life support is started. Return of spontaneous circulation is achieved after several minutes. Vital signs are repeated; temperature is 81 ºF (27.2 ºC), pulse is 36/min, respiratory rate is 6/min, blood pressure is 71/49 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 88% on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe hypothermia (temperature < 82 ºF, or 28 ºC) with hemodynamic instability and subsequent cardiac arrest. Warmed IV fluids would not be adequate treatment in this case, and invasive rewarming measures, such as hemodialysis or extracorporeal bypass, should be started. Since this patient also has severe hypoxemia, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) would be preferred to provide cardiopulmonary bypass, warm the blood, and provide oxygenation.

Hypothermia can be classified as mild (90-95 ºF, or 32-35 ºC), moderate (82-90 ºF, or 28-32 ºC) or severe (<82 ºF, or <28 ºC). Treatment centers around providing supportive care, warming the patient, and treating complications. External rewarming (e.g. heating blankets) should be initiated immediately. Internal rewarming (e.g. warmed IV fluids) should be provided for moderate and severe hypothermia. Patients with severe and/or refractory hypothermia can be treated with invasive rewarming measures. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable or in cardiac arrest, these include ECMO, hemodialysis, cardiopulmonary bypass, or peritoneal or closed thoracic lavage with warmed fluid.  ECMO is typically preferred in cases of severe hypothermia with cardiac arrest.  

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate extracorporeal membrane oxygenation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Initiate hemodialysis:
Incorrect: This could be an option to provide internal rewarming, especially if the patient has severe acute kidney injury. This patient just had a cardiac arrest and is persistently hypoxemic, so ECMO is more appropriate.  
❌ Initiate room temperature IV fluids  :
Incorrect: Patients with moderate or severe hypothermia should receive warmed IV fluids.  
❌ Initiate warmed IV fluids:
Incorrect: This is appropriate for moderate or severe hypothermia. However, this patient has already suffered a cardiac arrest due to hypothermia and needs more aggressive treatment.  
❌ Apply warming blankets:
Incorrect: This is appropriate for patients with mild hypothermia, but it is not adequate for moderate or severe hypothermia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance due to lethargy. His past medical history is significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, and his chronic medications include insulin glargine, insulin lispro, and lisinopril. The patient had a wisdom tooth extracted four days ago and has been taking hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5 mg two times per day since then. His appetite and oral intake have been very poor due to tooth pain, and he is currently constipated. Temperature is 36.6 ºC (97.9 ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 112/65 mmHg, respiratory rate is 12/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 98% on room air. On examination, the patient is lethargic but awakens easily and is fully oriented. Pupils are sluggish, normal size, and symmetrically reactive. There are no skin lacerations or needle marks. The patient’s skin is slightly diaphoretic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Patients with severe hypoglycemia, which is likely the case in this patient, can present similarly to patients with opioid intoxication/overdose. This patient was taking two doses per day of low-dose hydrocodone which is unlikely to cause significant intoxication or overdose in an adult. This patient’s pupils are not miotic (constricted), pointing away from opioid intoxication. In addition, the patient is slightly diaphoretic, which is common in opioid withdrawal but not intoxication or overdose. The patient’s poor oral intake likely led to bigger drops in blood glucose when using the same dose of insulin. Therefore severe hypoglycemia is more likely in this case, and the first step is to check a point-of-care glucose level.
 

Patients with opioid intoxication may initially experience euphoria, apathy, or dysphoria. On presentation, patients have decreased mentation, and they may have slurred speech or severe lethargy. Pupils can be sluggish and miotic (constricted) but are generally not fixed. Respiratory drive is preserved. Patients using IV drugs may have needle marks. Patients with an opioid overdose may present similarly, but they are generally very lethargic. Unlike opioid intoxication, patients with an overdose will have significant hypotension and/or respiratory depression (often SpO2 <90%).  

Option Analysis

✅ Check a point-of-care glucose level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV naloxone:
Incorrect: This would be the next step for opioid overdose. This patient’s presentation could be opioid intoxication, but is more concerning for hypoglycemia (he does not have constricted pupils or signs of respiratory depression on examination). A point-of-care glucose should be performed before considering further management.  
❌ Check a urine drug screen:
Incorrect: While this may be of clinical utility, diagnosing and treating the patient acutely is more important than ordering a urine drug screen. After the acute management is in place, then a urine drug screen can be obtained.  
❌ Perform endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: This would be indicated for respiratory distress, severe respiratory depression, or an inability to protect the airway (e.g. significantly altered mental status). This patient has no respiratory distress and has adequate oxygenation..  
❌ Administer subcutaneous methylnaltrexone:
Incorrect: Methylnaltrexone is a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist. It is used for opioid-induced constipation. Though the patient is suffering from constipation, this would not be the first step in management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner after he was found trying to catch his breath in the driveway. The patient is an agricultural worker on a nearby farm. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder and anxiety.
