Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 40/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. Physical examination reveals a lethargic and diaphoretic man with bilateral pinpoint pupils and watering from the eyes. The patient’s body and clothes are soiled in vomit and feces. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral diffuse wheezing with rhonchi. The patient’s clothes are removed, and skin is irrigated. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with dyspnea, bradycardia, miosis, and evidence of excessive secretions. These findings are suggestive of cholinergic toxicity. Most cases result from exposure to organophosphate pesticides.  

Managing organophosphate poisoning includes stabilization (e.g. maintaining airway), removing contaminated clothes, and reversing cholinergic hyperstimulation. Atropine is the prototypical nonselective acetylcholine blocker that competes with acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. The medication should be administered immediately, leading to the resolution of muscarinic symptoms (e.g.. bronchospasm, bradycardia, salivation).    

However, atropine does not prevent acetylcholine binding with nicotinic receptors and is ineffective in treating symptoms associated with nicotinic receptor overstimulation (e.g., fasciculations, myoclonic jerks, paralysis). As a result, patients are also treated with pralidoxime, which reactivates acetylcholinesterase and promotes acetylcholine breakdown.  

In addition to treating organophosphate poisoning, atropine can treat bradycardia by blocking the “rest and digest” effects. It decreases bladder smooth muscle contraction and helps prevent nocturnal enuresis in children. Ophthalmologists can also use atropine to dilate the pupils.  



Option Analysis

❌ Administration of sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate is indicated in treating tricyclic antidepressant overdose, presenting with altered mental status and anticholinergic signs (e.g., flushed skin, mydriasis, tachycardia). In contrast, this patient presents with cholinergic symptoms.  
❌ Initiation of hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is sometimes used to treat severe alcohol poisoning. Alcohol poisoning can present with altered mental status, vision changes (methanol), flank pain, and hematuria (ethylene glycol). Hemodialysis is not indicated in the treatment of cholinergic toxicity.  
✅ Administration of atropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Evaluation using methemoglobin test:
Incorrect: Methemoglobin levels should be obtained as part of the work-up for methemoglobinemia, which can occur after the administration of dapsone or the topical anesthetic benzocaine. Patients typically present with cyanosis, dyspnea, and headaches.  
❌ Initiation of antitoxin therapy:
Incorrect: Antitoxin therapy is indicated in patients with botulism, typically presenting with descending muscle weakness and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, constipation). This patient’s cholinergic symptoms and clinical history suggest organophosphate poisoning.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found down outside. Past medical history is significant for mild generalized anxiety disorder and hypertension. Current medications include daily lisinopril and a few doses per week of as-needed hydroxyzine. The patient is currently experiencing homelessness. He consumes between one or two beers per week and does not drink to the point of intoxication. Temperature is 91.4 ºF (33 ºC), pulse is 54/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, blood pressure is 116/78 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is somnolent but awakens easily to provide history. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for hypothermia in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with mild hypothermia (temperature between 90-95 ºF, or 32-35 ºC). He is currently experiencing homelessness which is his main risk factor for hypothermia. Immediate treatment should include supportive care and external rewarming. Once the patient is stabilized, a social worker or case manager should be consulted to help with this patient’s living situation.

Hypothermia is defined as a core temperature < 95 ºF (35 ºC). It can be caused by medical conditions (e.g., myxedema coma, sepsis) but usually occurs due to prolonged exposure to cold. The most common risk factors include excessive alcohol use (inebriation and poor perception of temperature), older age (dysfunctional thermal regulation), homelessness, and psychiatric conditions. Patients will present with shivering, altered respiratory rates (hyper- or hypoventilation), and frequent alterations in mental status. Bradycardia is very common and can be related to sinus bradycardia, junctional arrhythmias, atrioventricular block, or other arrhythmias. Electrocardiographic abnormalities such as J waves may also be present.

Hypothermia can be classified as mild (90-95 ºF, or 32-35 ºC), moderate (82-90 ºF, or 28-32 ºC), or severe (<82 ºF, or <28 ºC). Treatment centers around providing supportive care, warming the patient, and treating any complications. External rewarming (e.g. heating blankets) should be initiated immediately. Internal rewarming (e.g. warmed IV fluids) should be provided for moderate and severe hypothermia. Patients with severe and/or refractory hypothermia may need extracorporeal life support to provide more active rewarming.   

Option Analysis

✅ Housing status:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Older age is a significant risk factor for hypothermia. This patient is only 40 years old, which is not a significant risk factor.  
❌ Alcohol use:
Incorrect: Significant alcohol use is a strong risk factor for hypothermia due to intoxication and impaired judgment or sensation of cold temperatures. However, this patient consumes alcohol only once or twice a week and does not drink to the point of intoxication.  
❌ Anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: Severe and/or uncontrolled psychiatric disorders place patients at risk for hypothermia. This patient’s generalized anxiety disorder is mild and not a significant risk factor.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not a specific risk factor for hypothermia.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services after being found on the ground. The patient was walking outside this morning without adequate clothing and did not remember anything until she woke up in an ambulance. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 85 ºF (29.4 ºC), pulse is 42/min, respiratory rate is 10/min, blood pressure is 98/53 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic but answers orientation questions appropriately when awoken. The patient is shivering, and the skin is cold. There are no abnormal heart or lung sounds on auscultation. Serum creatinine is 2.3 mg/dL (1.0 mg/dL two years ago). Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with moderate hypothermia (temperature between 82-90 ºF, or 28-32 ºC) with the expected signs of bradycardia, hypoventilation, and decreased mentation. Treatment for moderate hypothermia, as seen in this case, should include supportive care, external rewarming, and internal rewarming with warmed IV fluids.

Hypothermia is defined as a core temperature < 95 ºF (35 ºC). It can be caused by some medical conditions (e.g., myxedema coma, sepsis) but usually occurs due to prolonged exposure to cold. The most common risk factors include excessive alcohol use (inebriation and poor perception of temperature), older age (dysfunctional thermal regulation), homelessness, and psychiatric conditions. Patients will present with shivering, altered respiratory rates (hyper- or hypoventilation), and frequent alterations in mental status. Bradycardia is very common and can be related to sinus bradycardia, junctional arrhythmias, atrioventricular block, or other arrhythmias. Electrocardiographic abnormalities, such as J waves (prominent convex deflections at the J point) may also be present.

Hypothermia can be classified as mild (90-95 ºF, or 32-35 ºC), moderate (82-90 ºF, or 28-32 ºC), or severe (< 82 ºF, or < 28 ºC). Treatment centers around providing supportive care, warming the patient, and treating any complications. External rewarming (e.g. heating blankets) should be initiated immediately. Internal rewarming (e.g. warmed IV fluids) should be provided for moderate and severe hypothermia. Patients with severe and/or refractory hypothermia may need extracorporeal life support to provide more active rewarming.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer warmed IV fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer room temperature IV fluids:
Incorrect: This intervention would be appropriate for initial resuscitation for patients with mild hypothermia who respond well to external rewarming measures. This patient has moderate hypothermia and should undergo internal warming.  
❌ Initiate extracorporeal membrane oxygenation:
Incorrect: This intervention would be appropriate for severe hypothermia if there is hemodynamic instability or cardiac arrest. Warmed IV fluids are more appropriate at this time.  
❌ Initiate hemodialysis with warmed fluids:
Incorrect: This intervention would be appropriate for severe hypothermia unresponsive to other measures, especially if associated with severe acute kidney injury. This patient’s kidney injury is mild, and warmed IV fluids are more appropriate at this time.  
❌ Provide a warm blanket:
Incorrect: This intervention would be appropriate for initial management of patients with mild hypothermia. This patient has moderate hypothermia and should undergo internal warming, as well.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by a friend due to a suspected drug overdose. The patient is lethargic and cannot provide a history. The friend states that the patient had a wisdom tooth extracted two days ago. The patient’s prescription bottle for twenty pills of oxycodone-acetaminophen was found with the patient, and only two pills remain in the bottle. Temperature is 37.2 ºC (99.0 ºF), pulse is 60/min, blood pressure is 102/57 mmHg, respiratory rate is 8/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 89% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic, awakens easily, but falls back to sleep within a few seconds. Pupils are constricted, symmetric, and reactive to light bilaterally. Which of the following medications should be administered at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an opioid overdose as suggested by lethargy, miotic pupils, missing oxycodone-acetaminophen pills, and severe respiratory depression. IV naloxone should be given immediately to prevent complications or death from respiratory depression.

Patients with opioid intoxication may initially experience euphoria, apathy, or dysphoria. On presentation, patients have decreased mentation and may have slurred speech or lethargy. Pupils can be sluggish and miotic (constricted) but are generally not fixed. Respiratory drive is preserved. Patients with opioid overdose may present similarly but are generally very lethargic. Unlike opioid intoxication, patients with an overdose will have significant hypotension and/or respiratory depression (often SpO2 < 90%).
 

Patients with an overdose should be given IV naloxone, a mu-opioid receptor antagonist which can reverse the central nervous system effects of opioids. Additional acute measures include obtaining IV access, continuously monitoring vital signs, providing IV fluids and supplemental oxygen, and possible intubation.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV naloxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Oral naltrexone:
Incorrect: Naltrexone is used for treating chronic opioid use disorder rather than acute intoxication. In addition, this patient is extremely lethargic and cannot safely swallow pills, so IV medications should be used.  
❌ Subcutaneous methylnaltrexone:
Incorrect: Methylnaltrexone is a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist. It is used for opioid-induced constipation. It does not reverse CNS effects of opioid overdose/intoxication and would not be of significant benefit.  
❌ Oral methylnaltrexone:
Incorrect: Methylnaltrexone is a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist. It is used for opioid-induced constipation. It does not reverse CNS effects of opioid overdose/intoxication and would not be of significant benefit.  
❌ Oral naloxegol:
Incorrect: Naloxegol is a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist. It is used for opioid-induced constipation. It does not reverse CNS effects of opioid overdose/intoxication and would not be of significant benefit.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department via ambulance after a friend found the patient confused at home. According to the friend, the patient has been sleeping more than usual lately and has not had a bowel movement in a week. The patient has no significant medical history and is not taking any prescribed medications. Temperature is 36.5 ºC (97.7 ºF), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic with sluggish miotic pupils. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is unremarkable. Abdominal exam is significant for hypoactive bowel sounds. Serum sodium is 133 mEq/L and bicarbonate is 20 mEq/L. Venous pCO<sub>2</sub> is 58 mmHg. Which of the following findings is an indication for giving IV naloxone?
questions.solution:
This patient’s signs and symptoms (lethargy, confusion, constipation, sluggish but reactive pupils) are concerning for opioid overdose. However, they can also be signs of opioid intoxication for which observation is the usual treatment. Laboratory studies indicating an elevated venous pCO2 in this patient signifies respiratory depression causing inadequate ventilation and is a clear indication of overdose for which IV naloxone should be given. IV naloxone should be given to any patient with signs of opioid overdose.

Patients with opioid intoxication may initially experience euphoria, apathy, or dysphoria. On presentation, patients have decreased mentation and may have slurred speech, lethargy, and constipation. Pupils can be sluggish and miotic (constricted) but are generally not fixed. In contrast to opioid overdose, respiratory drive is preserved in opioid intoxication. Patients using IV drugs may have needle marks.

Patients with an opioid overdose may present similarly, but they are generally very lethargic. Unlike opioid intoxication, patients with an overdose may have significant hypotension and/or respiratory depression (often SpO2 <90%). In addition to vital sign abnormalities of hypotension and decreased oxygenation, blood gas testing may show respiratory acidosis, as seen in this patient, indicating hypoventilation and the need for IV naloxone.  

Option Analysis

✅ Venous pCO2 measurement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum bicarbonate level:
Incorrect: Metabolic acid-base derangements can occur for many reasons in acute illness or drug overdose. These changes are much slower than respiratory acid-base changes and do not reflect acute respiratory depression and the need for IV naloxone.  
❌ Lethargy:
Incorrect: This may be present in opioid intoxication or overdose. But lethargy alone is not an indication for IV naloxone. If the patient was unable to be awakened or aroused, that could indicate opioid overdose and be an indication to give naloxone in the right clinical circumstances.  
❌ Sluggish pupils:
Incorrect: Pupils can be sluggish and miotic (constricted) in both intoxication and overdose. In overdose, the miotic pupils may also be fixed and not reactive to light (‘pinpoint”) which could be an indication for IV naloxone.  
❌ Constipation:
Incorrect: Constipation can be present in opioid intoxication or overdose, but there are many other causes of constipation. This is not a particularly distinctive feature and would not be an indication for giving IV naloxone.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by family members due to hypothermia. Last night, the patient fell asleep on a hammock outside, and she was found by family this morning. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. Current medications include empagliflozin, metformin, and ramipril. Vital signs are taken, and the patient is found to be hypothermic and bradycardic. Prior to performing a physical examination, a family member asks about the severity of this patient’s hypothermia. Which of the following features, if present, would be most specific for moderate hypothermia?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypothermia after being found outside by family. Initial treatment should include supportive care and external rewarming. If the patient has moderate hypothermia, defined as a core temperature of 82–90 ºF (28–32 ºC), then internal rewarming should also be provided.

Hypothermia is defined as a core temperature < 95 ºF (35 ºC). It can be caused by medical conditions (e.g., myxedema coma, sepsis) but usually occurs due to prolonged exposure to cold. The most common risk factors include excessive alcohol use (inebriation and poor perception of temperature), older age (dysfunctional thermal regulation), homelessness, and psychiatric conditions. Patients will present with shivering, altered respiratory rates (hyper- or hypoventilation), and frequent alterations in mental status. Bradycardia is very common and can be related to sinus bradycardia, junctional arrhythmias, atrioventricular block, or other arrhythmias. Electrocardiographic abnormalities, such as J waves, may also be present.

Hypothermia can be classified as mild (90-95 ºF, or 32-35 ºC), moderate (82-90 ºF, or 28-32 ºC), or severe (<82 ºF, or <28 ºC). Treatment centers around providing supportive care, warming the patient, and treating complications. External rewarming (e.g. heating blankets) should be initiated immediately. Internal rewarming (e.g. warmed IV fluids) should be provided for moderate and severe hypothermia. Patients with severe and/or refractory hypothermia may need extracorporeal life support to provide more active rewarming.  

Option Analysis

✅ Core temperature of 86 ºF (30 ºC)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Core temperature of 91 ºF (32.8 ºC)  :
Incorrect: A core temperature of 90-95 ºF (32-35 ºC) falls within the classification for mild hypothermia.  
❌ Sinus bradycardia:
Incorrect: Sinus bradycardia can occur with all degrees of hypothermia, but it can also occur for many other unrelated reasons.  
❌ Junctional arrhythmia:
Incorrect: Significant arrhythmias are more likely with higher degrees of hypothermia but are not specific to any core body temperature.  
❌ Altered mental status:
Incorrect: Altered mental status is more likely with higher degrees of hypothermia, but it is not specific to any core body temperature.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police officers after he and several friends were found in an abandoned house producing and using recreational drugs. The patient endorses blurry vision and a headache for the past two hours. Past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, and treatment-resistant depression. Current medications include aspirin, lisinopril, metoclopramide, metoprolol, and selegiline. Temperature is 99.1 ºF (37.3 ºC), heart rate is 108 bpm, respiratory rate is 18 bpm, blood pressure is 205/116 mmHg. The patient appears agitated and slightly confused. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia and an S4 sound. The neurologic exam is unremarkable. Several of the patient’s friends demonstrated evidence of slow movement, rigidity, and a resting tremor on physical examination. Which of this patient’s medications protected him from experiencing the physical exam findings observed in his friends?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a hypertensive crisis, presumably a hypertensive emergency in light of his altered mental status. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI), such as selegiline, can cause serotonin syndrome when combined with other serotonergic medications and can also lead to hypertensive crises. Selegiline is an MAO-B subtype-specific MAOI that is often used to treat Parkinson disease given its role in dopamine metabolism.  

This patient’s friends have likely been exposed to the neurotoxin MPTP, which can be produced as an unintended product during the synthesis of recreational drugs (e.g. opioids). MPTP and its active metabolites can induce damage to the substantia nigra and result in the development of Parkinsonian features. Since MPTP cannot be broken down into active metabolites by MAO-B, selegiline offers a relative neuroprotective effect against MPTP neurotoxicity.

Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: While aspirin can help prevent cerebrovascular accidents, which can cause permanent neurologic changes, it is unlikely that it is preventing Parkinsonism.
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril can help reduce risk of myocardial infarction, ventricular remodeling and inappropriate renin-angiotensin-aldosterone activity, it does not prevent the development of Parkinsonism.
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide is an anti-dopaminergic agent that can cause Parkinsonism features.
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol does not prevent Parkinsonism
✅ Selegiline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department on a cold winter night for evaluation of colicky behavior. The parent reports the infant has been increasingly fussy over the past 24 hours with decreased feeding. There is no history of fever, cough, congestion, nausea, or vomiting. The infant was born full term without complications during pregnancy or delivery and has been meeting developmental milestones. The parent reports that the patient’s mother and older sibling are currently at home with a headache and nausea. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 170/min, blood pressure is 90/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, the infant appears fatigued but is arousable with tactile stimulation. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Point-of-care blood glucose testing is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with colicky behavior and reduced feeding during the winter months. Several family members at home are also experiencing non-specific symptoms such as headache and nausea. Together, these findings suggest carbon monoxide poisoning.  Additional risk factors for this condition may include the use of wood-burning stoves, kerosene heaters, old furnaces, or indoor fireplaces.

Inhalation or ingestion of various household substances can cause significant morbidity and mortality in children. Increased mobility and frequent hand-to-mouth behavior during the toddler and preschool years increase the risk of unintentional or exploratory exposures. While some toxins, such as lead, typically cause vague, subacute, or chronic symptoms, exposure to caustic agents, carbon monoxide, organophosphates, or toxic alcohols can lead to acute, potentially life-threatening presentations.

Careful history and physical examination often help identify the most likely cause. Key clinical features and historical clues for common ingestions are summarized in the chart below.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Lead poisoning:
Incorrect: Lead poisoning is unlikely in a non-ambulatory infant without known exposure to lead-containing sources such as peeling paint in older homes or contaminated water from lead pipes. When symptomatic, children often present with developmental delays, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, or anemia.
✅ Carbon monoxide poisoning:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Organophosphate toxicity:
Incorrect: Organophosphate poisoning causes a cholinergic toxidrome, characterized by diarrhea, urinary frequency, pinpoint pupils, bronchospasm, bradycardia, vomiting, lacrimation, and excessive salivation. These features are not present in this infant.
❌ Button battery ingestion:
Incorrect: Ingestion of a button battery usually causes caustic injury to the esophagus and leads to symptoms such as drooling, vomiting, dysphagia, or respiratory distress. This clinical presentation does not match the current history.
❌ Ethylene glycol ingestion:
Incorrect: Ethylene glycol poisoning typically presents with nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. A history of exposure is common, and symptoms usually do not involve multiple household members.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after being found with an open, unmarked bottle of liquid in the living room. The child is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 108/min, blood pressure is 105/67 mmHg, respiratory rate is 27/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the child appears fatigued. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. A venous blood gas reveals a pH of 7.42. Additional laboratory findings are obtained and detailed below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

 Laboratory value Result
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium 142 mEq/L
 Potassium 4.2 mEq/L
 Chloride  107 mEq/L
 Bicarbonate 28 mEq/L
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 18
 Creatinine 0.5 mg/dL
  Glucose 90
 Albumin 3.2 g/dL
 Serum osmolality 328 mOsm/kg

 Urinalysis
 Color Clear
 Specific gravity 1.013
 Glucose Negative
 Blood Negative
 Leukocyte esterase Negative
 Nitrites Negative
 Leukocytes 1-2/hpf
 Erythrocytes 1-2/hpf
 Dysmorphic RBCs Absent
 Ketones Large
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents following an unwitnessed ingestion of an unknown liquid. Laboratory findings show ketosis and an elevated osmolar gap of 33 mOsm/kg (calculated using the formula below) without a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. These findings strongly suggest toxic alcohol ingestion, specifically isopropyl alcohol. Isopropyl alcohol is commonly found in hand sanitizers, rubbing alcohol, and some household cleaning products. It is metabolized to acetone, which causes ketosis without an anion-gap metabolic acidosis. It is often associated with a “fruity” breath odor.

Formulating and prioritizing a differential diagnosis in a pediatric patient with a household substance exposure depends on a careful history and physical examination. Patients often have a history of witnessed ingestion or known exposure to a specific toxin, such as organophosphates. Most present with nonspecific symptoms like nausea and vomiting accompanied by vital sign abnormalities. In non-verbal pediatric patients, important clues such as the presence of open containers, pill bottles, or similar symptoms in family members can help narrow the differential diagnosis.

Basic laboratory testing should be obtained to assess for metabolic abnormalities or anemia, as seen in cases like lead poisoning. For suspected toxic alcohol ingestion, findings on a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and serum osmolality can help distinguish between different alcohols, as outlined in the table above.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Methanol toxicity:
Incorrect: Methanol toxicity typically follows ingestion of windshield washer fluid or industrial solvents. Laboratory findings would usually show an elevated osmolar gap and a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis, the latter of which is not present here.
✅ Isopropyl alcohol toxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ethylene glycol toxicity:
Incorrect: Ethylene glycol toxicity occurs after ingestion of antifreeze. Laboratory findings would usually show an elevated osmolar gap and a high anion-gap metabolic acidosis, the latter of which is not present here.
❌ Ethanol toxicity:
Incorrect: While acute ethanol toxicity is also associated with an elevated osmolar gap without a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, the presence of large ketones in the urine is more consistent with isopropyl alcohol toxicity.
❌ Organophosphate toxicity:
Incorrect: Organophosphate toxicity presents with symptoms of a cholinergic toxidrome, including diarrhea, urinary frequency, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia, emesis, lacrimation, and salivation (DUMBBELS mnemonic). This patient's physical examination shows no such findings.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his parent because of bizarre behavior, confusion, and hallucinations. A neighbor had advised the mother that several neighborhood youths had been taken to nearby hospitals after ingesting wildflowers and developing similar symptoms. The patient is mumbling, shaking, and picking at nonexistent items in the emergency room. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows flushed skin and dry oral mucosa. The pupils are dilated and nonreactive to light and accommodation. Bowel sounds are decreased. Which of the following substances can help reverse this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hallucinations, confusion, flushed skin, and dry mucous membranes. He has anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to ingestion of jimson weed flowers. Jimson weed contains large concentrations of the anticholinergic compounds atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine.  

The classic anticholinergic (technically “antimuscarinic”) syndrome is remembered as “red as a beet” (flushed skin), “hot as a hare” (hyperthermia), “dry as a bone” (dry mucous membranes, no sweating), “blind as a bat” (blurred vision, cycloplegia), and “mad as a hatter” (confusion, delirium). Patients usually have sinus tachycardia and dilated pupils. Agitated delirium or coma may be present. Muscle twitching is common, but seizures are unusual unless the patient has ingested an antihistamine or tricyclic antidepressant, which can also cause anticholinergic symptoms. Urinary retention is common, especially in older men.  

The antidote for the anticholinergic toxidrome is intravenous physostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that counteracts the effects of anticholinergic drugs by preventing the degradation of acetylcholine. Intravenous physostigmine is given if the individual presents with both peripheral and central anticholinergic toxicity, such as anhidrosis from peripheral toxicity and delirium from central toxicity.  



Option Analysis

❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an anticholinergic agent and can be used to reverse organophosphate poisoning (cholinesterase inhibitors). This patient's history and symptoms are more consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. A cholinesterase inhibitor is indicated for the reversal of this patient’s symptoms.   
✅ Physostigmine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is an opioid pain medication that exerts its effects on the brain. In contrast, this patient has symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity. Morphine would not be useful in reversing this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reverse acute opioid toxicity. This patient's history and symptoms are more consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. A cholinesterase inhibitor is indicated for the reversal of symptoms.   
❌ Thiamine:
Incorrect: Thiamine (B1) supplementation is usually given to patients who are chronically deficient due to alcohol use disorder or malnutrition, which, if untreated, can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation following concern for a household ingestion. The child was found by a caregiver in the bathroom with several open containers of cleaning solutions. The caregiver reports that the patient was initially asymptomatic but has become stuporous over the past hour. The child is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 25/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued and has a fruity odor on the breath. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. A point-of-care blood glucose test is normal. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on further workup?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents after an unwitnessed ingestion of cleaning solutions and shows stupor along with a fruity odor on examination. These findings most strongly suggest toxic alcohol ingestion, which is typically associated with an elevated osmolar gap. The fruity odor is likely due to isopropyl alcohol ingestion, as its metabolism produces acetone, which causes the characteristic smell.

History and physical examination often provide critical clues to the underlying diagnosis. Important historical details include a witnessed ingestion, the presence of empty containers such as cleaning products, or symptoms that are often nonspecific, including headache, nausea, or vomiting. Vital sign abnormalities are common, and physical findings may be specific to the type of ingestion, such as oral mucosal injury in caustic detergent ingestion or a fruity breath odor in toxic alcohol poisoning. Key historical and physical examination features for different types of ingestion are summarized in the chart above.

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated lead level :
Incorrect: Lead poisoning usually presents with a history of ingestion of paint chips or exposure to old plumbing materials. Acute stupor and fruity breath odor are not typical features of lead toxicity.
✅ Elevated osmolar gap:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated carboxyhemoglobin level:
Incorrect: Carbon monoxide poisoning typically presents with headache, dizziness, nausea, and sometimes altered mental status, often affecting multiple individuals exposed to the same source. Fruity breath odor is not associated with this condition.
❌ Oropharyngeal ulceration:
Incorrect: Oropharyngeal ulceration is more commonly seen after ingestion of caustic substances such as drain cleaners or laundry detergents. Patients with caustic ingestion often present with drooling, difficulty swallowing, oral pain, and swelling. These symptoms would not typically cause stupor or fruity breath odor.
❌ Elevated ethanol level:
Incorrect: Ethanol ingestion typically causes central nervous system depression but usually does not produce a fruity odor on the breath. The presence of stupor combined with fruity breath odor and normal blood glucose favors ingestion of a toxic alcohol rather than ethanol.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a well child visit. The patient was born at full term, and immunizations are up to date. Maternal history includes seizures (controlled with medication), alcohol intake, and cigarette smoking. The parent reports the child has always been healthy, though a bit small for age. Compared to siblings, development is mildly delayed, and the patient has a poor attention span. Weight and height are at the 5th and 10th percentiles for age, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 95/51 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, short palpebral fissures, a thin vermilion border, and a smooth philtrum are noted. A loud, harsh, holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. Prenatal exposure to which of the following best explains the findings?
questions.solution:
This 3-year-old patient presents with developmental delays, growth restriction, and characteristic facial features; this constellation of findings is consistent with fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD). FASD refers to a range of physical, behavioral, and neurodevelopmental effects resulting from prenatal alcohol exposure.        

When a pediatric patient presents with concerns suggesting prenatal teratogen exposure, it is essential to obtain a focused history and physical examination. If there are no signs of opioid withdrawal, a history of medical conditions associated with teratogenicity, or prenatal exposure to medications, alcohol exposure should be considered.        

Alcohol use during pregnancy, in any amount, can have significant adverse effects on the developing fetus, including restricted growth, cardiac defects (e.g., atrial, or ventricular septal defects), renal anomalies (e.g., hypoplastic or horseshoe kidneys), skeletal defects (e.g., pectus carinatum, radioulnar synostosis), and eye or ear anomalies. Older children often demonstrate cognitive delays, poor attention span, and behavioral problems. Characteristic facial features, such as short palpebral fissures, a thin vermilion border, and a smooth philtrum, are commonly observed. Epicanthal folds, midface hypoplasia, hypoplastic nails, and “railroad track” ears (which refers to an underdeveloped upper ear that appears in parallel to a crease below) can also be seen with FASD.   

Option Analysis

✅ Alcohol :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phenytoin  :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to phenytoin is associated with abnormal bleeding, impaired development, and characteristic craniofacial abnormalities (e.g., wide anterior fontanelle, short nose, bowed upper lip, cleft lip, or palate). The features noted in this case, including the short palpebral fissures, thin vermilion border, and smooth philtrum, are more consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome.  
❌ Tetracycline  :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to tetracycline can result in brown or yellow-stained teeth. It does not cause the characteristic facial features of short palpebral fissures, thin vermilion border, and smooth philtrum, which are more indicative of fetal alcohol syndrome. 
❌ Tobacco   :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to tobacco is associated with low birth weight and developmental delays, without characteristic facial features. The observed short palpebral fissures, thin vermilion border, and smooth philtrum are more consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome.  
❌ Valproate :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to valproate leads to club feet, wide skull, high forehead, midface hypoplasia, and a broad, low nasal bridge. The features of short palpebral fissures, a thin vermilion border, and a smooth philtrum, in this case, are more consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of recurrent vomiting. The child was found vomiting in the laundry room while playing with laundry detergent packets. The patient was last seen in his usual state of health 2 hours ago. The patient has no past medical history and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 150/min, blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears ill, with noted respiratory distress, drooling, and stridor. Intravenous (IV) access is established, supplemental oxygen is applied, a normal saline bolus is administered, and the patient is connected to telemetry. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents following ingestion of a laundry detergent capsule, raising concern for caustic ingestion. Caustic substances can cause liquefactive necrosis of the esophagus and upper airway, leading to stridor and drooling. Given the risk for airway instability, the best next step in management is securing the airway via fiberoptic endotracheal intubation. This approach allows clear visualization of the upper airway and esophagus, minimizing further injury.

Many pediatric patients with caustic injury may initially present without symptoms but can quickly decompensate, making clinical suspicion crucial in suspected cases. In these situations, patients should undergo gastroenterology consultation for endoscopy and surgical consultation if perforation is suspected. Additionally, a local poison center should be contacted for further guidance on management and disposition.

All patients with suspected exposure to household substances should be evaluated using the ABCDE approach to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Caustic substances, carbon monoxide, organophosphates, and toxic alcohols can cause acute, life-threatening symptoms. Patients with airway instability should have their airway secured, with particular attention to preventing aspiration or further damage to surrounding structures. Breathing should be supported with supplemental oxygen, and circulation should be stabilized with intravenous fluids if signs of dehydration or hemodynamic instability, such as hypotension, are present.   

Option Analysis

❌ Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) placement:
Incorrect: Blind placement of upper airway adjuncts such as laryngeal mask airways (LMAs) are strictly contraindicated in patients with suspected caustic ingestion. Blind placement may worsen esophageal injury.
✅ Fiberoptic endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activated charcoal:
Incorrect: This patient is at high risk of respiratory decompensation given the concern for caustic ingestion. There is no role for activated charcoal in the management of caustic agents. Charcoal may obscure visualization during endoscopy or intubation and can cause vomiting, which could re-expose the upper gastrointestinal tissues to the caustic agent.
❌ Syrup of ipecac:
Incorrect: Syrup of ipecac is no longer recommended following ingestion of household substances. It was previously used to induce vomiting, but studies show that vomiting alone does not reliably remove poisons from the stomach. Moreover, it risks re-exposing the upper gastrointestinal tissues to the caustic agent.
❌ Bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP):
Incorrect: Application of bilevel positive airway pressure could increase the risk of aspiration and worsen respiratory distress by interfering with swallowing and breathing coordination. It may also cause gastric distention, which can further compromise respiratory status.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services for altered mental status. The patient was found unconscious in a running vehicle in an apartment parking garage. There was evidence of recent vomiting at the scene. Past medical history is unknown. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 24/min and shallow, blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on 10 L/min via nonrebreather mask. The patient is confused, disoriented, and somnolent. Fundoscopy reveals retinal hemorrhages and papilledema. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute encephalopathy, likely due to carbon monoxide poisoning, as evidenced by confusion, disorientation, and somnolence after being found unconscious in an idling vehicle. Tachypnea, hypoxia despite noninvasive respiratory support, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., retinal hemorrhages, papilledema) indicate the need for intubation and mechanical ventilation in order to protect the airway, ensure adequate oxygenation, and control ventilation.

Encephalopathy, which refers to a change from a patient’s baseline cognitive status, can range from mild confusion to coma and can result from a variety of causes, including neurologic conditions, toxic-metabolic states, nutritional deficiencies, and infections.

The ABCDE approach is a structured method for rapidly assessing and stabilizing critically ill individuals, including those with acute or subacute encephalopathy. It begins with an Airway assessment to ensure patency, followed by Breathing to evaluate respiratory effort and oxygenation. Supplemental oxygen or intubation may be required for airway or respiratory compromise. Circulation focuses on assessing perfusion, blood pressure, and heart rate, with administration of IV fluids or vasopressors as needed. Disability involves a quick neurological assessment, and Exposure ensures identification of any external clues (e.g., trauma, rashes, toxins) while maintaining temperature regulation.  

All unstable patients should have continuous vital sign monitoring, and IV access should be obtained. Additional measures for those with increased intracranial pressure may include elevating the head of the bed, hyperventilation, or hyperosmolar therapy.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741 or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.   

Option Analysis

✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Arterial blood gas:
Incorrect: While an arterial blood gas can be helpful in the evaluation of suspected carbon monoxide toxicity, this patient’s tachypnea, hypoxia, and signs of increased intracranial pressure are indications for immediate airway and breathing stabilization with intubation and mechanical ventilation.
❌ Carboxyhemoglobin level:
Incorrect: While a carboxyhemoglobin level can be helpful in the evaluation of suspected carbon monoxide toxicity, this patient’s altered mental status, hypoxia despite supplemental oxygen, and signs of increased intracranial pressure are indications for immediate airway and breathing stabilization with intubation and mechanical ventilation.  
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: While neuroimaging can be helpful in the evaluation of a patient presenting with signs of increased intracranial pressure, it should not be pursued prior to stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. In this case, intubation and mechanical ventilation are warranted.
❌ Continuous video electroencephalography (EEG):
Incorrect: While continuous EEG monitoring can be helpful in the evaluation of a patient presenting with altered mental status, this patient’s tachypnea, hypoxia, and signs of increased intracranial pressure are indications for immediate airway and breathing stabilization with intubation and mechanical ventilation.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic for regular follow-up. He currently has no symptoms other than fatigue, which he attributes to an increased workload. Past medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no regular medications except occasional ibuprofen for joint pain in the hands. He does not smoke cigarettes and does not drink alcohol. Family history is significant for liver transplantation in the patient's brother at age 40 due to end-stage liver disease. Temperature is 37oC (98.6 F), heart rate is 80 bpm, respirations are 18, and blood pressure is 130/95 mmHg. The patient’s skin appears bronze. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. On abdominal examination, the lower border of the right liver lobe is felt 5 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following represents the primary management for this patient’s diagnosis?

 Laboratory value   Results 
 Hemoglobin   14 g/dl 
 Platelets   165000 / mm3 
 Leukocyte count   7500/mm3 
 INR   1.1 
 Iron   430 µg/l 
 Ferritin  560 μg/L 
 Transferrin saturation  69% 
 AST  96 U/L 
 ALT   60 U/L 
 Albumin   3.6 g/dl 
 Bilirubin (Total)  0.6 mg/dl 
 HBA1C  8%
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of fatigue, arthropathy, family history of liver transplantation, and elevated serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels strongly point to a diagnosis of primary hemochromatosis. Regular phlebotomy is the mainstay of treatment for patients with primary hemochromatosis without heart failure or end-stage liver disease. The frequency of the phlebotomy is tailored to the iron profile. The target ferritin level is < 300 μg/L. Importantly, hemoglobin levels should be checked before each phlebotomy session with a target hemoglobin level of 12-13 g/dl. For patients with primary hemochromatosis who have a  contraindication to phlebotomy (e.g., anemia, heart failure, poor venous access) or in cases where phlebotomy has been inadequate, chelating agents like deferasirox can be used.  

An alternative treatment option to phlebotomy is erythrocytapheresis, which involves the selective removal of red blood cells without removing blood components, such as proteins and thrombocytes. Erythrocytapheresis should be considered in patients with thrombocytopenia or hypoproteinemia. In patients with end-stage liver failure, surgery should be consulted to evaluate for liver transplantation. In addition to phlebotomy, patients should be counseled on lifestyle modifications including avoidance of alcohol which can increase the risk of cirrhosis in an already susceptible liver, and avoidance of iron and vitamin C supplements. Genetic screening and counseling should be offered to all first-degree relatives of patients with primary hemochromatosis.  

Patients with hemochromatosis have an increased risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma and should have a thorough liver assessment. If liver fibrosis is indicated by persistently elevated liver function tests, or if the serum ferritin levels are greater than 1000 nanograms per milliliter, abdominal ultrasound with elastography, an MRI of the liver, or liver biopsy should be performed to determine the presence and degree of fibrosis, and to predict progression to cirrhosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Phlebotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dexrazoxane:
Incorrect: Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent used to lessen the iron-mediated oxidative effect of doxorubicin (i.e., a chemotherapeutic agent) on cardiac muscle.
❌ Desferasirox:
Incorrect: Deferasirox is an iron chelating agent used in patients with primary hemochromatosis when regular phlebotomy is contraindicated or inadequate (e.g., anemia, heart failure, poor venous access).
❌ Liver transplantation:
Incorrect:  Liver transplantation is indicated in patients with end-stage liver disease. This patient has normal albumin, INR, and total bilirubin with mild elevations in the liver enzymes (e.g., AST, ALT) and does not need liver transplantation at this time.
❌ Vitamin C supplementation:
Incorrect: Vitamin C supplementation increases the ferrous form of iron, thus increasing iron absorption. Like alcohol, vitamin C should be avoided in patients with hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old G2P1 woman at 11 weeks’ gestation presents to the obstetrical office to establish care and discuss fetal aneuploidy screening. The patient’s prior pregnancy resulted in a full-term, healthy vaginal delivery 10 years ago. Otherwise, the patient has no other significant past medical history. Because of a phobia of needles, the patient declines maternal serum screening and opts for a nuchal translucency (NT) scan. The NT measurement is above the 99th percentile for crown-rump-length, which is confirmed on subsequent comprehensive ultrasonography. Further amniocentesis or other genetic testing is declined. Which of the following would be the most common autosomal chromosomal abnormality associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
This 37-year-old patient presents at 11 weeks’ gestation with a nuchal translucency (NT) scan above the 99th percentile. The NT scan measures the fluid-filled space normally seen along the dorsal aspect of the fetal neck. An increased NT measurement (≥3 mm or >99th percentile for crown-rump-length) is associated with fetal aneuploidy and certain structural abnormalities. The most common viable autosomal chromosomal aneuploidies are trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome), and trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome). 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) is the most common sex-chromosome aneuploidy, while 45,X (Turner syndrome) is the only viable monosomy. Although all of these aneuploidies can present with an increased NT, trisomy 21 is the most common.       

When used alone, NT screening has poor sensitivity and specificity. If the NT measurement is normal, patients should be counseled about the residual risk of aneuploidy and may consider additional screening options. If NT measurement is increased, referral for genetic counseling, a comprehensive ultrasound examination for structural abnormalities, and a discussion about further screening or confirmatory diagnostic testing are indicated.    

Option Analysis

✅ Trisomy 21:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 47,XXY:
Incorrect: This patient’s NT scan demonstrates an increased NT measurement, which is associated with fetal aneuploidy. 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome) is the most common sex-chromosome aneuploidy; it is not an autosomal aneuploidy.  
❌ 45,X:
Incorrect: This patient’s NT scan demonstrates an increased NT measurement, which is associated with fetal aneuploidy. 45, X (Turner syndrome) is the only viable monosomy. However, it is a sex chromosome aneuploidy, not an autosomal aneuploidy.  
❌ Trisomy 18:
Incorrect: This patient’s NT scan demonstrates an increased NT measurement, which is associated with fetal aneuploidy. While Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) is an autosomal aneuploidy, it is not as common as trisomy 21. 
❌ Trisomy 13:
Incorrect: This patient’s NT scan demonstrates an increased NT measurement, which is associated with fetal aneuploidy. While trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is an autosomal aneuploidy, it is not as common as trisomy 21.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parent for a routine evaluation. The boy has a known medical condition that requires frequent checkups. The parent states that the patient has been healthy, except for frequent episodes of chronic diarrhea. Current medications include an inhaled bronchodilator, an inhaled corticosteroid, and inhaled N-acetylcysteine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Weight is at the 5th percentile for age and height is at the 10th. There is painless swelling of the distal phalanges. Which of the following tests should be done at this visit?
questions.solution:
This boy, who is coming in for a routine evaluation, likely has cystic fibrosis (CF). Previously considered lethal in infancy and early adolescence, patients with CF can now survive to a median age of 50 years. This improvement is mainly due to early diagnosis through neonatal screening, routine evaluation, and improved pharmacotherapies.  

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) can be used to track CF progression. PFTs are used to determine the severity of pulmonary exacerbations as well as disease progression. Pulmonary exacerbations present with increased sputum production, chronic cough, and lung function decline noted by pulmonary function testing.  

Additionally, chest x-rays (CXRs) are a common diagnostic tool to follow disease progression. CXRs are extremely useful for diagnosing chronic infection as well as preventing and managing pulmonary exacerbations. In patients with early disease, CXRs may show hyperinflation. As the disease progresses, bronchiectasis, air trapping, and hyperinflation become more prominent on radiographs.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Chest x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Routine echocardiogram would be useful in patients with congenital heart defects. Although it can also present with failure to thrive, patients do not typically present with loose stools or chronic rhinosinusitis. 
❌ Slit lamp eye examination:
Incorrect: Slit lamp eye examination should be performed in patients who are predisposed to anterior uveitis, such as children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Patients typically complain of swollen joints that are painful with movement, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient. 
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Regular screening with abdominal ultrasounds is typically done in patients with congenital syndromes that predispose them to abdominal tumors, such as WAGR and Beckwith-Widemann. 
❌ Colonoscopy :
Incorrect: Colonoscopy should be routinely performed in patients 8 years after the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis to screen for colorectal cancer. Although this patient is presenting with diarrhea and failure to thrive, his other symptoms make another diagnosis more likely.
